Clinical services include HTC, ART, HIV/TB, PMTCT/RCH and lab services. The program is implemented by TPDF HQ, clinics, Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.8: Orphans and Vulnerable Children. Activities are aimed at improving the lives of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) affected by HIV/AIDS, and doing so in a measurable way. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.2: Sexual Prevention - Abstinence/Be Faithful. Activities (including training) to promote abstinence, fidelity, reducing multiple and concurrent partners, and related social and community norms that impact these behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. PAI’s objective is to mitigate HIV impact on Tanzania Peoples Defense Forces (TPDF) by addressing drivers of the epidemic and support the provision of quality HIV/AIDS services for 32,000 military officers, their dependents and 300,000 civilians living near the military camps. Clinical services include HTC, ART, HIV/TB, PMTCT/RCH and lab services. The program is implemented by TPDF HQ, clinics, colleges, community support groups and MOHSW. PAI provides TA and direct support to facilities and communities in collaboration with the MOHSW, LGAs and other partners to achieve national goals. Close collaboration with RHMTs and CHMTs has been established so that TPDF sites benefit from MOHSW resources. The eight zonal military hospitals are acting as hubs that support a network of 61 health facilities located in TPDF barracks and camps. The plan is to continue capacity building and strategic infrastructural improvement in more than 65 clinics countrywide. Peer education and ‘life-skills’ trainings will focus on enhancing cross cutting issues such as Gender, Behavior Change while QI will aim to build zonal oversight capacity for quality services. The current plan is to strengthen QI, linkages, retention and M&E systems involvement of expert PLHAs, community volunteers and internal human resources.
Over the past two years, PAI’s funding was reduced due to significant pipeline but activities have now ramped up resulting in accelerated pipeline reduction. It is projected that PAI will have only three months of pipeline beyond FY2014. In FY 2014 intense project monitoring and supervision coupled with TPDF zonal hospitals approach to function as hubs to serving satellite sites within their zones will raise the unit expenditure and burn rates as compared with FY 2013.
